abstract_sentences.1: Deep Neural Networks (DNNs) have provably enhanced the state-of-the-art Neural Machine Translation (NMT) with their capability in modeling complex functions and capturing complex linguistic structures.
abstract_sentences.2: However NMT systems with deep architecture in their encoder or decoder RNNs often suffer from severe gradient diffusion due to the non-linear recurrent activations, which often make the optimization much more difficult.
abstract_sentences.3: To address this problem we propose novel linear associative units (LAU) to reduce the gradient propagation length inside the recurrent unit.
abstract_sentences.4: Different from conventional approaches (LSTM unit and GRU), LAUs utilizes linear associative connections between input and output of the recurrent unit, which allows unimpeded information flow through both space and time direction.
abstract_sentences.5: The model is quite simple, but it is surprisingly effective.
abstract_sentences.6: Our empirical study on Chinese-English translation shows that our model with proper configuration can improve by 11.7 BLEU upon Groundhog and the best reported results in the same setting.
abstract_sentences.7: On WMT14 English-German task and a larger WMT14 English-French task, our model achieves comparable results with the state-of-the-art.

https://doi.org/10.18653/v1/P17-1013  1 Introduction  Neural Machine Translation (NMT) is an endto-end learning approach to machine transla-
tion which has recently shown promising results on multiple language pairs (Luong et al., 2015; Shen et al., 2015; Wu et al., 2016; Zhang et al., 2016; Tu et al., 2016; Zhang and Zong, 2016; Jean et al., 2015; Meng et al., 2015).
body_sentences.2: Unlike conventional Statistical Machine Translation (SMT) systems (Koehn et al., 2003; Chiang, 2005; Liu et al., 2006; Xiong et al., 2006; Mi et al., 2008) which consist of multiple separately tuned components, NMT aims at building upon a single and large neural network to directly map input text to associated output text.
body_sentences.3: Typical NMT models consists of two recurrent neural networks (RNNs), an encoder to read and encode the input text into a distributed representation and a decoder to generate translated text conditioned on the input representation (Sutskever et al., 2014; Bahdanau et al., 2014).
body_sentences.4: Driven by the breakthrough achieved in computer vision (He et al., 2015; Srivastava et al., 2015), research in NMT has recently turned towards studying Deep Neural Networks (DNNs).
body_sentences.7: (2016) found that deep architectures in both the encoder and decoder are essential for capturing subtle irregularities in the source and target languages.
body_sentences.8: However, training a deep neural network is not as simple as stacking layers.
body_sentences.9: Optimization often becomes increasingly difficult with more layers.
body_sentences.10: One reasonable explanation is the notorious problem of vanishing/exploding gradients which was first studied in the context of vanilla RNNs (Pascanu et al., 2013b).
body_sentences.11: Most prevalent approaches to solve this problem rely on short-cut connections between adjacent layers such as residual or fastforward connections (He et al., 2015; Srivastava et al., 2015; Zhou et al., 2016).
body_sentences.12:

body_sentences.13: Through this design, information can flow across several steps both in time and in space with little attenuation.
body_sentences.14: The mechanism makes it easy to train deep stack RNNs which can efficiently capture the complex inherent structures of sentences for NMT.
body_sentences.15: Based on LAUs, we also propose a NMT model , called DEEPLAU, with deep architecture in both the encoder and decoder.
body_sentences.16: Although DEEPLAU is fairly simple, it gives remarkable empirical results.
body_sentences.17: On the NIST Chinese-English task, DEEPLAU with proper settings yields the best reported result and also a 4.9 BLEU improvement over a strong NMT baseline with most known techniques (e.g, dropout) incorporated.
body_sentences.18: On WMT English-German and English-French tasks, it also achieves performance superior or comparable to the state-of-the-art.
body_sentences.19: 2 Neural machine translation  A typical neural machine translation system is a single and large neural network which directly models the conditional probability p(y|x) of translating a source sentence x = {x1, x2, · · · , xTx} to a target sentence y = {y1, y2, · · · , yTy}.
body_sentences.20: Attention-based NMT, with RNNsearch as its most popular representative, generalizes the conventional notion of encoder-decoder in using an array of vectors to represent the source sentence and dynamically addressing the relevant segments of them during decoding.
body_sentences.21: The process can be explicitly split into an encoding part, a decoding part and an attention mechanism.
body_sentences.22: The model first encodes the source sentence x into a sequence of vectors c = {h1, h2, · · · , hTx}.
body_sentences.23: In general, hi is the annotation of xi from a bi-directional RNN which contains information about the whole sentence with a strong focus on the parts of xi.
body_sentences.24: Then, the RNNsearch model decodes and generates the target translation y based on the context c and the partial traslated sequence y<t by maximizing the probability of p(yi|y<i, c).
body_sentences.25:
In the atten-
tion model, c is dynamically obtained according to the contribution of the source annotation made to the word prediction.
body_sentences.26: This is called automatic alignment (Bahdanau et al., 2014) or attention mechanism (Luong et al., 2015), but it is essentially reading with content-based addressing defined in (Graves et al., 2014).
body_sentences.27: With this addressing strategy the decoder can attend to the source representation that is most relevant to the stage of decoding.
body_sentences.28: Deep neural models have recently achieved a great success in a wide range of problems.
body_sentences.29: In computer vision, models with more than 100 convolutional layers have outperformed shallow ones by a big margin on a series of image tasks (He et al., 2015; Srivastava et al., 2015).
body_sentences.30: Following similar ideas of building deep CNNs, some promising improvements have also been achieved on building deep NMT systems.
body_sentences.32: (2016) proposed a new type of linear connections between adjacent layers to simplify the training of deeply stacked RNNs.
body_sentences.34: (2016) introduced residual connections to their deep neural machine translation system and achieve great improvements.
body_sentences.35: However the optimization of deep RNNs is still an open problem due to the massive recurrent computation which makes the gradient propagation path extremely tortuous.
body_sentences.36: 3 Model Description  In this section, we discuss Linear Associative Unit (LAU) to ease the training of deep stack of RNNs.
body_sentences.37: Based on this idea, we further propose DEEPLAU, a neural machine translation model with a deep encoder and decoder.
body_sentences.38: 3.1 Recurrent Layers  A recurrent neural network (Williams and Zipser, 1989) is a class of neural network that has recurrent connections and a state (or its more sophisticated memory-like extension).
body_sentences.39: The past information is built up through the recurrent connections.
body_sentences.40: This makes RNN applicable for sequential prediction tasks of arbitrary length.
body_sentences.41:
Given a sequence of vectors x = {x1,x2, · · · ,xT } as input, a standard RNN computes the sequence hidden states h = {h1,h2, · · · ,hT } by iterating the following
equation from t = 1 to t = T :
ht = φ(xt,ht−1) (1)
φ is usually a nonlinear function such as composition of a logistic sigmoid with an affine transformation.
body_sentences.42: 3.2 Gated Recurrent Unit  It is difficult to train RNNs to capture longterm dependencies because the gradients tend to either vanish (most of the time) or explode.
body_sentences.43: The effect of long-term dependencies is dropped exponentially with respect to the gradient propagation length.
body_sentences.44: The problem was explored in depth by (Hochreiter and Schmidhuber, 1997; Pascanu et al., 2013b).
body_sentences.45: A successful approach is to design a more sophisticated activation function than a usual activation function consisting of gating functions to control the information flow and reduce the propagation path.
body_sentences.46: There is a long thread of work aiming to solve this problem, with the long short-term memory units (LSTM) being the most salient examples and gated recurrent unit (GRU) being the most recent one (Hochreiter and Schmidhuber, 1997; Cho et al., 2014).
body_sentences.47: RNNs employing either of these recurrent units have been shown to perform well in tasks that require capturing long-term dependencies.
body_sentences.48: GRU can be viewed as a slightly more dramatic variation on LSTM with fewer parameters.
body_sentences.49: The activation function is armed with two specifically designed gates called update and reset gates to control the flow of information inside each hidden unit.

body_sentences.54: Here we propose LAU which extends GRU by having an additional linear transformation of the input in its dynamics.

body_sentences.195: 5 Conclusion  We propose a Linear Associative Unit (LAU) which makes a fusion of both linear and nonlinear transformation inside the recurrent unit.
body_sentences.196: On this way, gradients decay much slower compared to the standard deep networks which enable us to build a deep neural network for machine translation.
body_sentences.197: Our empirical study shows that it can significantly improve the performance of NMT.
